results.title: The Circle = Dayereh = Il Cerchio [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi, Jafar Panahi Film Productions, Lumière & Co. and Mikado Film Srl (Rome)
results.brief_description: From Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi (The White balloon), comes “The Circle” a tale of female oppression in modern day Iran. “The Circle” opens in a hospital maternity ward where a woman has just given birth. Her mother is horrified by the catastrophic outcome - its a girl. She had been assured (via ultrasound) that it would be a boy and laments the fact that a divorce will ensue and her daughter will be shamed. This opening sequence reflects the status of women in Iran, as unwanted, second-class citizens without rights or a voice in society. “The Circle” tells the stories of several women in a city over the course of one day and night. Simple acts of buying a bus ticket or smoking a cigarette in public are denied to women and are punishable by law. The women of the film, in constant danger of imprisonment and harassment, are shunned by their families and seek refuge with each other. Panahi adopts a documentary style for this feature film, as street noise fills the soundtrack and the camera follows the characters around, almost hounding them. “The Circle” was banned in Iran due to its controversial subject matter. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Golden Lion, Best Film at the 2000 Venice Film Festival)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jafar Panahi, Jafar Panahi Film Productions, Lumière & Co. and Mikado Film Srl (Rome)

results.title: Food preservation
results.creator_credit: Hugh Hudson, Cammell Hudson and Unilever Films
results.brief_description: Discusses modern developments in food preservation, including quick-freezing and canning. Also shows by animation and microphotography the growth and decay of cells, and the effect of bacterial action in the cell breakdown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hugh Hudson, Cammell Hudson and Unilever Films

results.title: Food from the reluctant earth
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the cereal belt area of South Australia, where farmers must grow crops without irrigation and maintain livestock with a minimum of water. Explains the wheat/legume rotation system that enables farmers to obtain high yields.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edwin Scragg, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Flute and piccolo
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Basic Music Techniques”.
One of a series of films designed to assist the musician and the music lover. In this film professional musicians show how the flute and piccolo are played, their range tone, and how to care for them. Consultant: Verdon Williams (conductor).

results.title: Flame cutting
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Gas Welding”.
Demonstrates the correct adjustment for flame cutting, which is the result of a chemical reaction between a ferrous chemical and oxygen.

results.title: Rupert Murdoch
results.creator_credit: Ken Hannam, Kip Porteous and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Five Australians”
Looks at the personal life of Rupert Murdoch the newspaper tycoon, whose career started when he inherited the family company interests. He expanded the business and launched a national paper, The Australian. Members of his family and staff discuss the man they know.

results.title: Fires were started
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings, Stewart McAllister, Ian Dalrymple and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: A main contribution of Britain to the development of cinematography has been the creation of a distinctive school of film-making - the documentary film. Using non-professional actors “FIRES WERE STARTED” is the first feature film by Humphrey Jennings and is one of the most moving of the war documentaries, recapturing the typical atmosphere of the war on Britain’s civilian front. The film is a tribute to the work of the Auxiliary Fire Service, described through the events of one-day activities. The story unfolds without effort from the early morning assembly of crew at the fire station, through the routine of the day, to the fighting of a blazing warehouse at night.

results.title: The Feast
results.creator_credit: Timothy Asch and Documentary Educational Resources
results.brief_description: Illustrates the feasting practices of the Yanomamo Indians of southern Venezuela, at the headwaters of the Orinoco River. These feasts provide an opportunity for the forming of alliances between independent sovereign villages. Based on Chapter IV of Napoleon Chagnon’s ethnographic work, Yanomano: the fierce people.

results.title: The Expressive arts: everyone succeeds!
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Subjects such as music, drama, painting, pottery, sculpture and weaving are now being taught in schools. The study of these subjects is seen to enhance the social, physical, and emotional development of students, and it is argued that students are also inspired to put more effort into the traditional academic subjects. Photography by Edwin Scragg and edited by Wayne Le Clos.
